questions.question: Which of the following is not a feature of papilledema?
questions.explanation: Disruption of neurofilaments is not a feature of papilledema.Papilledema is the swelling of the optic nerve head secondary to raised intracranial pressure(ICP)."Disc swelling" and "disc edema" are non-specific terms that include papilledema but also indicatea disc swollen from other causes.All patients with papilledema should be suspected of harboring an intracranial mass.Features of papilledema:•Raised ICP• Edema of the optic nerve head• Blockage of axoplasmic flow•Axonal swelling• Collection of extracellular fluid• Painless progressive loss of vision•Enlargement of the blind spot• Color vision, visual acuity, and pupillary reaction are normal, until optic atrophy sets in.
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Optic Nerve and Gaze Palsies

questions.question: A resident notes the following fundus picture in a patient referred to the ophthalmology OPDwith visual complaints. What does it suggest?510DAILYROUNDS
questions.explanation: The fundoscopic image shows dilated veins with a blurred disc margin which is suggestive ofpapilledema.Ophthalmoscopic features of papilledema:•Early-stage:520•Obscuration of the disc margins (nasal margins first)• Absence of spontaneous venous pulsation at the disc• Mild hyperemia of the disc• The blurring of the peripapillary nerve fiber layer• Established papilledema:• The disc appears to be enlarged and elevated (mushroom or dome-shaped)•Macular fan appears•• Paton's lines- circumferential greyish white folds may develop due to the separation of nervefibers• Visual fields show enlargement of the blind spot• Veins become tortuous and engorged• Multiple cotton-wool spots and superficial hemorrhages• Chronic or long-standing (vintage) papilledema:• The optic disc gives the appearance of the dome of a champagne cork.Small drusen-like crystalline deposits (corpora amylacea) may appear on the disc surface•Atrophic stage:• Secondary optic atrophy

questions.question: Which of the following conditions show ipsilateral optic atrophy and contralateralpapilledema?
questions.explanation: Ipsilateral optic atrophy and contralateral papilledema are seen in Foster-Kennedy syndrome.Weber syndrome (superior alternating hemiplegia) is a form of stroke characterized by thepresence of an ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy and contralateral hemiparesis or hemiplegia.Millard-Gubler syndrome is a lesion of the pons. It is also called ventral pontine syndrome.Benedikt syndrome, also known as paramedian midbrain syndrome, involves the fasciculus ofoculomotor nerve as it passes through the red nucleus and is characterized by ipsilateral thirdnerve palsy and contralateral extrapyramidal signs such as hemitremor.

questions.question: A 45-year-old man presents to the casualty with a sudden loss of vision and painful ocularmovements. On examination, the eye is white and there are no obvious signs onophthalmoscopy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of a sudden painful loss of vision in the absence of fundoscopicchanges is suggestive of retrobulbar neuritis.There are 3 types of optic neuritis: papillitis, neuroretinitis, and retrobulbar neuritis. The commoncauses of retrobulbar neuritis include demyelinating disorders such as multiple sclerosis (MS) andneuromyelitis optica (NMO or Devic's disease).521Clinically, optic neuritis is characterized by sudden, progressive visual loss. Ocular movementsare painful in retrobulbar neuritis and painless in papillitis and neuroretinitis. Glowing sensationsknown as phosphenes may be induced with sound or movement. Color vision may also beimpaired.On examination, Marcus Gunn pupil or relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is usually noteddue to asymmetric involvement. The most common visual field defect is a central or centrocecalscotoma.The image below shows papillitis.TypePathologyFundus appearancePrevalenceRetrobulbar neuritisInflammation of the optic nerve behind the discOptic disc appears normalMost common in adultsAssociated conditio Strong association with demyelinating disorders likeMS, NMOnsPapillitisInflammation of the optic nerve headHyperemia and oedema ofthe optic disc with or without peri-papillary flame-shaped hemorrhagesMost common in childrenWeak association with demyelinating disordersNeuroretinitisInflammation of the optic nerve head and the maculaMacular star (due to exudates that form around macula)Least common typeCat-scratch disease, Lymedisease, Syphilis etc.The image below shows macular star appearance in neuroretinitis.522

questions.question: A 33-year-old patient has come to the ophthalmology OPD with complaints that her visionbecomes temporarily blurry after a hot bath in the evening. This resolves by itself after a fewhours. She has a past history of an episode of painful unilateral optic neuritis, 3 months backwhich resolved with steroids. What is being described here?
questions.explanation: Episodic, transient obscuration of vision on exertion or on exposure to heat, which recovers onresting or moving away from the heat in an isolated optic neuritis patient is called Uhthoffphenomenon. It is commonly associated with multiple sclerosis (MS).Option A: Pulfrich's phenomenon is an illusion of depth perception. It is seen in MS.Option C: Lhermitte's sign refers to passive neck flexion causing an electric shock-like sensationradiating to the spine and shoulders. This is a result of the increased sensitivity of the myelin tostretch or traction; it is also seen in MS.Option D: Riddoch phenomenon refers to ability to perceive kinetic but not static targets. It isseen in cortical blindness.

questions.question: In a patient with multiple sclerosis, which of the following visual field defects is most likely?
questions.explanation: Central scotoma is more likely to occur with multiple sclerosis. It is also seen with retrobulbarneuritis and macular pathology.Option A: Optic chiasma compression causes bitemporal hemianopiaOption C: Enlarged blind spot occurs with papilloedemaOption D: Tunnel vision occurs in glaucoma, retinitis pigmentosa and Retinal panphotocoagulation

questions.question: Optic neuritis is a common presentation in which of the following diseases?
questions.explanation: 523One of the common presentations of MS is optic neuritis. Multiple sclerosis (MS) results fromdemyelinating plaques in the central nervous system.Option A: Myasthenia gravis is the autoimmune destruction of the acetylcholine receptors at theneuromuscular junction.Option B: Guillain-Barré syndrome is the postinfectious autoimmune-induced destruction ofperipheral nerves, resulting in an ascending paralysis.Option D: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a disease of the motor nerve fibers of the lateralcolumns and anterior horns of the spinal cord that results in progressive muscular atrophy.

questions.question: A 26-year-old female patient presents with 6/60 visual acuity in one eye and 6/18 in the othereye. She has recurrent episodes of diminution of vision which recovers on treatment withsteroids. She also has a history of transverse myelitis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical vignette of a patient presenting with decreased visual acuity and a history oftransverse myelitis which is treated with steroids is indicative of Neuromyelitis optica (NMO).Neuromyelitis optica also known as Devic's disease is an autoimmune demyelinating disease inwhich antibodies are formed against Aquaporin 4 present in the cell membranes of Astrocytes. Itis characterized by the findings of unilateral or bilateral optic neuritis developing within a fewweeks of transverse myelitis (demyelination of the spinal cord). The disease may be monophasic orrecurrent.Diagnostic Criteria for Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder (NMOSD):Diagnostic Criteria for NMOSD associated with AQP4-IgG• At least 1 core clinical characteristic• A positive test for AQP4-IgG using the best available detection method (cell-based assay)• Exclusion of alternative diagnoses•Core Clinical Characteristics:Optic neuritis is usually bilateral and causes severe visual loss.• Acute myelitis- may be severe, transverse and typically longitudinally extensive involving threeor more contiguous vertebral segments.• Area postrema syndrome: episodes of otherwise unexplained hiccups or nausea or vomiting•• Acute brainstem syndrome•Symptomatic narcolepsy associated with NMOSD-typical diencephalic MRI lesionsFor acute cases of NMO, high-dose glucocorticoids or plasma exchange is used. Mycophenolatemofetil, rituximab, and glucocorticoids with azathioprine are used for prophylaxis againstrelapses.The FDA has approved satralizumab, a humanized IgG2 monoclonal antibody, for the treatmentof NMO spectrum disorder with AQP4 antibody positivity.Eculizumab, a complement inhibitor, and inebilizumab, a B-cell depletion agent, are two morenew drugs that have recently been approved for use in NMO attack prevention.524A history of transverse myelitis with optic neuritis (decreased visual acuity) rules out Multiplesclerosis (option D). It is an autoimmune inflammatory and demyelinating disease of the CNS thataffects both upper motor neurons (UMN) and lower motor neurons (LMN) with involvement ofsensory system, ocular system and bowel and bladder function. Ocular manifestations of MSinclude Optic neuritis (usually retrobulbar)- decreased visual acuity, internuclear ophthalmoplegiaand nystagmus.

questions.question: A middle-aged man with suspected optic neuropathy is being evaluated for visual fielddefects. Goldman perimetry reveals bilateral centrocecal scotomas. Which of the following ismost likely to be the causative agent?
questions.explanation: Centrocecal scotoma is most commonly seen in tobacco-induced amblyopia. It is also seen invitamin B12 deficiency.Tobacco amblyopia is caused by excessive smoking and chewing of tobacco. The toxic agentinvolved is cyanide found in tobacco. It is characterized by bilateral and gradually progressiveimpairment of central vision. The classic visual field defect is a centrocecal scotoma, ofteninvolving both the blind spot and the macula.Option B: Ethanol amblyopia is similar to tobacco amblyopia but often presents with peripheralneuritis and a "central scotoma".Option C: Methanol amblyopia often results in complete blindness.Option D: Quinine amblyopia results in near-complete blindness with associated deafness andtinnitus.

questions.question: An anxious, young man came to the ER with complaints of having sudden trouble seeing withhis left eye and a recent history of tripping over things. There was no associated pain ordifficulty moving the eyes. An ophthalmology consultation was requested. On perimetry, thefollowing visual field defect was picked up. What is the most likely diagnosis?A
questions.explanation: The perimetry result depicts altitudinal hemianopia, which is most commonly seen in anteriorischemic optic neuropathy (AION).Altitudinal hemianopia can also be seen in suprasellar tumors and occipital lobe lesions, but thefrequency is very low compared to that of AION. Hence, AION is the single best answer.The two types of AION are as follows:• Arteritic AION- caused by giant-cell arteritis•Non-arteritic AION (NAAION)- more commonClinical features:Note: Corticosteroids are not proven to be effective in NAAION.The image given below shows pale disc edema of Arteritic AION.FeaturesAAIONAge>70 yearsSexF> MHeadache Jaw claudicatiPresenton525NAAION<70 yearsF = MAbsentFeaturesVisual lossOptic discC reactive proteinESRFFAAAIONMarkedPale disc edemaRaisedHighly raisedNAAIONLess markedHyperemic disc edemaNormalRaisedDisc delay and choroidal dela Only disc delayyTreatmentCorticosteroidsLevodopa-carbidopa combination for 3 weeks and then double dose for 1 month

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is not associated with optic atrophy?
questions.explanation: Leprosy is not associated with optic atrophy.All the other given conditions can cause optic atrophy.Causes of optic atrophy:•Primary optic atrophy• Optic neuritis•Compression by tumors and aneurysms526• Hereditary optic neuropathies• Toxic and nutritional optic neuropathies• Trauma.Secondary optic atrophy• Chronic papilledema• Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy••PapillitisConsecutive optic atrophy• Extensive retinal photocoagulation• Retinitis pigmentosa• Prior central retinal artery occlusion•Glaucomatous optic atrophy

questions.question: A 24-year-old man with a history of pernicious anemia was referred to ophthalmology forcomplaints of gradually progressing visual disturbances. On perimetry, which of the followingdefects is most likely to be seen in him?
questions.explanation: The given scenario of pernicious anemia with gradually progressive visual disturbances issuggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency.B12 deficiency is known to cause centrocecal scotoma and it is an important cause of nutritionaloptic atrophy.

questions.question: A 15-year-old boy has bilateral optic atrophy with diabetes mellitus and diabetes insipidus.What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario suggests Wolfram syndrome. It is due to WFS1 gene mutation.The presentation is usually between the ages of 5 and 21 years; diabetes mellitus is typically thefirst manifestation, followed by visual problems. It has a poor prognosis.Clinical features are: (DIDMOAD)• Diabetes insipidus• Diabetes mellitus·• Optic atrophy• Deafness (sensorineural type)Option A: Kjer's optic neuropathy is an autosomal dominant condition. It presents with vision lossin early childhood and no significant systemic features.Option B: Behr syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition. Clinical features include opticatrophy, pyramidal tract signs, ataxia, intellectual disability, urinary incontinence, and pes cavusOption D: Leber's congenital amaurosis is an autosomal recessive condition. It usually presentswith significant vision loss in infancy and nystagmus.527

questions.question: Which of the following is not a feature of amaurosis fugax?
questions.explanation: Amaurosis fugax is a sudden and transient monocular blindness, which is reversible.It is a marker of advanced carotid artery atherosclerosis.

questions.question: Champagne cork disc is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: Champagne cork disc is seen in chronic papilledema.The optic disc gives the appearance of the dome of a champagne cork. Small drusen-likecrystalline deposits (corpora amylacea) may appear on the disc surface.The most reliable sign to differentiate between papillitis and papilledema is pupillary reaction.Pupillary light reflex is normal in papilledema whereas it is sluggish in papillitis.

questions.question: Which of the following defects is implicated in Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy?
questions.explanation: In Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON), the defect is a mutation of maternalmitochondrial DNA. Therefore the condition has a maternal inheritance.LHON causes bilateral, subacute painless loss of vision. The characteristic visual field defect is acentrocaecal scotoma. Pupillary light reflex is relatively preserved until the late stage of thedisease. Optic neuritis and optic atrophy start in one eye and goes on to involve the other eyesubsequently. It typically affects males between the ages of 15 and 35 years. The diagnosis ofLHON should be considered in any patient with bilateral optic neuropathy, irrespective of age.Prognosis is poor, although some visual recovery may occur in a minority of cases even yearslater.Note: LHON plus refers to rare variants with additional manifestations such as neuromusculardysfunction.

questions.question: A 34-year-old man developed a painless diminution of vision in his right eye 6 months agobut did not seek medical attention. Two weeks ago, he started to notice mild blurring in hisleft eye and has now come for evaluation. According to him, his elder brother and maternaluncle also had similar vision problems. Which fundus finding would point towards Leber'shereditary optic neuropathy in this patient?

options.C: Hyperemic optic disc with telangiectatic capillaries

questions.explanation: Hyperemic optic disc with telangiectatic capillaries would be suggestive of LHON.LHON is related to a mitochondrial DNA mutation. This results in impaired mitochondrialadenosine triphosphate production, which affects the highly energy-dependent optic nerve.In the acute phase, the optic disc is hyperemic and swollen with telangiectatic capillaries.However, the optic disc does not leak on fluorescein angiography. Later stages may show primaryoptic atrophy.528

questions.question: In order to diagnose a case as idiopathic intracranial hypertension, which of the followingfeatures is not necessary?

options.B: Elevated opening pressure on lumbar puncture

questions.explanation: Papilledema is not a mandatory criterion for the diagnosis of idiopathic intracranial hypertension(IIH).Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (pseudotumor cerebri) is a diagnosis of exclusion.Obstructive, compressive, and infiltrative CNS lesions must be excluded by neuroimaging studies.Papilledema, although present in 90% of the patients, is not necessary for diagnosis. Elevated CSFopening pressure on lumbar puncture is the hallmark of IIH.Risk factors of IIH include:• Female sex• Obesity•• Nalidixic acid⚫ Tetracycline•• Vitamin A• Oral contraceptives• Use of or withdrawal from corticosteroids

questions.question: Which of the following is the most reliable sign to clinically differentiate between a case ofpapillitis and papilledema?
questions.explanation: The most reliable sign to differentiate between papillitis and papilledema is pupillary reaction.Pupillary light reflex is normal in papilledema whereas it is sluggish in papillitis. Visual acuity andcolour vision are also relatively more preserved in papilledema compared to papillitis.The other three disc signs seen on ophthalmoscopy are present in both papillitis and papilledema.

questions.question: A patient evaluated for dizziness and visual disturbances was found to have down-beatingnystagmus. A brain lesion was suspected and the patient was referred for an MRI. What is the516most likely site of the lesion?

options.B: Pineal region and the dorsal midbrain

questions.explanation: Down-beat nystagmus is usually due to a lesion at the cervico-medullary junction (e.g.Arnold-Chiari malformation, syringobulbia) or as a manifestation of cerebellar degeneration.Other causes of down-beat nystagmus:• Drugs (phenytoin, lithium, barbiturates, carbamazepine)• Wernicke's encephalopathy• Demyelinating disordersAcquired nystagmus can be attributed to disturbances of the three mechanisms that normallyensure steady gaze-visual fixation, the vestibulo-ocular reflex, and the mechanism that makes itpossible to hold the eyes at an eccentric eye position (e.g. far-right gaze).Other types of nystagmus:529Type of NystagmusSlow-horizontalEtiologyLargeposterior cerebrallesions (e.g. stroke)Mixed horizontal (Torsional) Usually associated with vertiUp-beatPeriodic alternatingSee-sawGaze-evokedgo and seen investibular systemlesionsMedulla,the ventral tegmentum and the anterior vermis of the cerebellumCerebellar disease (In PAN, the horizontal jerk nystagmus spontaneously reverses the direction of the quick phase every few seconds)Lesion involvingparasellar region and optic chiasm(e.g. pituitary tumours, third ventricle)Side-effect ofdrugs, includingsedatives, anticonvulsants and alcohol, as well ascerebellardisease

questions.question: An RTA patient with severe head trauma is admitted to the surgical ICU for observation. Onexamination, nystagmus was noted. His CT scan reveals a transverse fracture of his lefttemporal bone. Which of the following statements is true regarding the nystagmus?

options.A: Slow phase is towards the left and fast phase towards the right
options.B: Slow phase is towards the right and fast phase towards the left
options.C: It is an up-beating type of nystagmus
options.D: It is a down-beating type of nystagmus

questions.explanation: Fracture of the temporal bone causes vestibular injury resulting in a horizontal nystagmus withslow phase towards the affected side and fast phase towards the opposite side.Peripheral vestibular nystagmus occurs in lesions of the labyrinth or vestibular nerve. Normally,there is tonic input to the brainstem vestibular nuclei from the periphery. Loss of the tonic inputfrom the left vestibular nerve leads to deviation of the eyes towards the left side, which is the slowphase of the nystagmus. The cortical correction brings the eyes back to the centre in the primarygaze which is the fast-phase directed towards the right side.

questions.question: Which of the following is the site of lesion in internuclear ophthalmoplegia?
questions.explanation: In internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) the lesion is at the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF).In INO, there is impaired adduction on the ipsilateral side of the lesion, and nystagmus onabduction on the contralateral side. When the gaze is initiated in the motor cortex, the horizontalgaze center or the paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) generates the eye movements.The PPRF has two outputs. The first is to the ipsilateral 6th cranial nerve nucleus which causesabduction of the ipsilateral eye. The second output is to the contralateral MLF which sends animpulse to the contralateral 3rd cranial nerve nucleus causing contralateral adduction. These twooutputs from PPRF lead to conjugate movement of the eyes to the same side.530Therefore, a lesion in the right MLF leads to failure of the right eye adduction. The left eye,however, abducts normally. This is called internuclear ophthalmoplegia.The following image shows the pathway for horizontal eye movements as described above.REPrimary gazeRight gaze(Normal)I/L adductionabsentLeft gaze(defect)LEC/L abduction presentwith nystagmusOMARROWAnatomical pathway for horizontaleye movementsRight FEFMR3rdMASRight EyeMLFPPRE6thLeft EyePPREFEFParamedian pontine reticular formationFrontal eye fieldMLFMRMedial longitudinal fasciculusMedial rectusLRLateral rectusOMARROWLR

questions.question: You are evaluating an elderly patient in the stroke ICU, who was admitted three days backwith a history of sudden onset nausea, vomiting, and gait abnormalities. The visualexamination showed conjugate horizontal left gaze palsy. He could maintain gaze nearmid-position but could not cross the midline to the left side. His MRI is likely to showinvolvement of which of the following brain areas?
questions.explanation: Horizontal gaze palsy can occur due to a lesion in parapontine reticular formation (PPRF).Horizontal gaze:• It involves 2 muscles- the ipsilateral lateral rectus and the contralateral medial rectus.• Center for this pathway is parapontine reticular formation (PPRF).• From here, they move to the ipsilateral 6th nerve nucleus.531• Next, they pass through the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) to the contralateral medialrectus subnucleus.Lesions affecting the abducens nuclei will also cause ipsilateral horizontal gaze palsy, because ofdamage to motor neurons and internuclear neurons originating from the nuclei. Lesions involvingthe PPRF will lead to horizontal gaze palsy, as PPRF acts as a relay centre that connects thefrontal eye fields in the cerebral cortex to the abducens nuclei. Conjugate horizontal gaze palsycan also be caused by lesion(s) involving both the abducens motor fibres and the MLFs precedingthe abducens nucleus. Bilateral horizontal gaze palsy will be caused if lesion(s) involve bothabducens nuclei or bilateral PPRF.Isolated damage to the MLFs will cause the classic INO where eye abduction is preserved,however, the ipsilateral eye will not be able to be adducted on conjugate horizontal gaze.Conjugate eye movements• Binocular movements in which the eyes move synchronously and symmetrically in the samedirection.• Main types• Saccades: They are fast movements controlled by the contralateral frontal lobe..• Pursuits: They are slow following movements controlled by the ipsilateral occipital lobe.Image: The Horizontal gaze pathwayAnatomical pathway for horizontaleye movementsRight FEFMR3rdMASRight EyeMLFPPRF6thLeft EyePPREFEFParamedian pontine reticular formationFrontal eye fieldMLFMRLRMedial longitudinal fasciculusMedial rectusLateral rectusOMARROWLR•Lesions in this pathwayHorizontal gaze palsy: Due to lesion in the PPRF of the same side• Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO): Caused by lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus(MLF)• One and a half syndrome: Caused by lesions in both MLF and PPRF of the same sideVertical gaze palsyCenter is located in the rostral interstitial nucleus of the dorsal midbrain (riMLF).532The important types of vertical gaze palsy are as follows:• Parinaud's syndrome: Upgaze palsy•Steel-Richardsons syndrome: Downgaze palsy

questions.question: A patient has normal vertical saccades. On attempted left gaze as shown in the image below,the patient develops left jerk nystagmus. Where is the most likely location of the lesion?
questions.explanation: The most likely location of the lesion according to the given clinical scenario and the image isthe right medial longitudinal fasciculus.The image depicts an attempted left gaze and concludes that there is an adduction deficit in theright eye. This causes jerk nystagmus in the abducting left eye.This is most likely due to a lesion of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) ipsilateral to theside of the adduction deficit. Hence, this is a case of a right MLF lesion or Right InternuclearOphthalmoplegia (INO).

questions.question: Ophthalmoplegic migraine clinically presents as

options.A: Headache with irreversible loss of optic nerve function
options.B: Headache associated with recurrent third nerve palsy
options.C: Headache associated with third, fourth, and sixth nerve palsy

questions.explanation: Ophthalmoplegic migraine refers to headache associated with third, fourth, and sixth nerve palsy.Ophthalmoplegic migraine almost always involves the third nerve. Rare cases of sixthnerve involvement, and even rarer cases that involve the fourth nerve, have also been reported.Clinical criteria for the diagnosis of ophthalmoplegic migraine include:• A prior history of typical common or classic migraine headaches• Ophthalmoplegia that occurs during (or, rarely, just before) an established migraine attack.Exclusion of other reasonable causes by clinical and radiological studies533
